Award.AwardTitle: An interdisciplinary approach to investigating mechanisms of vulnerability and resiliency following early-life adversity

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award was provided as part of NSF's Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships (SPRF) program and supported by SBE's Science of Learning program. The goal of the SPRF program is to prepare promising, early career doctoral-level scientists for scientific careers in academia, industry or private sector, and government. SPRF awards involve two years of training under the sponsorship of established scientists and encourage Postdoctoral Fellows to perform independent research. NSF seeks to promote the participation of scientists from all segments of the scientific community, including those from underrepresented groups, in its research programs and activities; the postdoctoral period is considered to be an important level of professional development in attaining this goal. Each Postdoctoral Fellow must address important scientific questions that advance their respective disciplinary fields. Under the sponsorship of Dr. Clancy Blair at New York University, this postdoctoral fellowship award supports an early career scientist investigating the social skill development of children growing up in environments of socioeconomic adversity. Nearly 20% of children in the United States are being raised in poverty. Impoverished families face a multitude of adversities, such as economic and housing obstacles, as well as difficulties seeking and maintaining employment. Such barriers can produce psychological stress and diminish time for family interactions and children's social skill development. The attainment of appropriate social skills is important for children's development across many areas of functioning, including mental health and academic achievement. Children with poor social skills are at higher risk for exhibiting violence, sexual offenses, and criminal behaviors in adolescence or adulthood. Despite the increased risk of poor social adjustment associated with living in poverty, some children exposed to poverty-related adversity have positive social adjustment. One finding that has consistently been linked to their resiliency is the presence of supportive adult-child relationships. The proposed studies will assess if quality peer relationships provide the same benefits that quality adult-child relationships provide in impoverished populations, by improving social development and biological regulation (i.e. stress physiology) despite exposure to poverty-related adversity. The studies are driven by the critical need to create readily accessible and scalable interventions to promote optimal social development for at-risk impoverished children.

The proposed research utilizes an innovative cross-species human/rodent approach to explore peer relationship quality as a potential target for interventions aimed at promoting social skill and stress physiology resiliency in at-risk, impoverished children. To this end, the proposed studies will draw on existing data from the Family Life Project, a longitudinal sample of 1,292 human children recruited at birth (oversampled for poverty status), in order to complete longitudinal modeling related to the impact of poverty-related adversity on social skills and stress physiology, and the mediating role of peer relationships. The proposed research will also leverage a scarcity-adversity rodent model to study neurobiological mechanisms by which resource scarcity impacts the development of social behavior, and test interventions of neurobehavioral repair grounded in social learning theory. These interventions will aim to improve the quality of peer interactions via naturalistic and pharmacological manipulations. This research will inform the creation of targeted, sensitive, and scalable interventions for the improvement of child social skill development in high-risk environments

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project utilized a cross-species human/rodent research approach to explore how social contexts can “get under the skin” to serve as sources of vulnerability or resiliency to children as they develop within the broader context of resource scarcity (e.g., poverty).

The fellow found evidence that growing up in scarcely resourced environments can negatively impact children’s social, cognitive, and academic outcomes. Furthermore, research findings provided novel evidence that these outcomes appear to be influenced in part by the child’s social contexts, such that transmission of stress from a parent to their child within contexts of resource scarcity can influence the long-term development of the child’s stress physiology. However, findings also revealed that child outcomes are malleable, and sensitive social interactions with parents and/or peers can provide children with resilient or improved social and cognitive development despite exposure to environmental scarcity. Such resilience appears to be imparted when parents or peers can socially buffer or rescue “typical” stress physiology functioning, although further research is required to better discern these underlying mechanisms. These findings underscore the importance of considering developing stress physiology and subsequent social and cognitive development in relation to a child’s broader social context when designing interventions for at-risk youth.

Completion of this fellowship yielded significant professional training opportunities which positively contributed to the fellow’s career development. The fellow gained invaluable training in conducting longitudinal research and statistical analyses, as well as immunoassay techniques. The fellow also established a novel integrative human and animal program of research to enhance mechanistic research related to poverty and child neurobehavioral development, which led to the initiation of interdisciplinary collaborations among multiple principal investigators in the broader NYC region. This integrative approach led to the translational validation of a rodent model of “scarcity-adversity,” for the study of the impact of resource scarcity on child development. Furthermore, this project provided substantial research, training, and publication opportunities for a minority undergraduate thesis student who was mentored by the fellow.

Research findings were disseminated via oral and poster presentations at national and international scientific meetings, as well as multiple peer-reviewed publications in scientific journals.The fellow’s findings on the importance of positive social experiences for fostering healthy cognitive development and enhancing academic ability were also disseminated to local nonprofit organizations serving low-income youth to help inform their strategies in best supporting at-risk youth throughout the COVID-19 pandemic, and similarly to public lay audiences via www.thesocialcreatures.org. The materials on the Social Creatures website have been viewed over 7,000 times (and counting) since its launch on April 24th, 2020.

Further completion of this project's training objective on science outreach and science communication also led to the launch of the "Digital Safety Nets" campaign on the Social Creatures website in direct response to school shutdowns and social distancing due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Through this campaign the fellow was able to procure donations for computers, internet hot-sports, and/or distance learning software (preloaded with books and learning materials). These supplies were distributed to a total of 250 low-income children and families who could not otherwise connect to distance learning and social support options. The Digital Safety Nets campaign remains ongoing and continues to scaling  to bridge the digital divide and social connectedness gaps that disproportionately impact low-socioeconomic status families. Since completion of this fellowship, the fellow is expanding upon this initial outreach by formally incorporating "Social Creatures," as an applied social science non-profit organization focused on ensuring that any individual can socially connect with others, no matter the circumstances. Through this newly established organization the fellow will continue to draw from this project's key research findings (and the broader literature), to bring an interdisciplinary, applied research approach to solving long-standing opportunity and equity gaps faced by low-income families and youth.
